Validations.name: Validations
Validations.description:
## Running Manual Validations

Although validations are lazily computed, there are times where we might want to force all or
specific validations to happen. For this reason we have exposed three methods:

- {{#crossLink "Factory/validate:method"}}{{/crossLink}}: Will always return a promise and should be used if asynchronous validations are present
- {{#crossLink "Factory/validateSync:method"}}{{/crossLink}}: Should only be used if all validations are synchronous. It will throw an error if any of the validations are asynchronous
- {{#crossLink "Factory/validateAttribute:method"}}{{/crossLink}}: A functional approach to validating an attribute without changing its state

Accessing Validations.name: Accessing Validations

Common Options.name: Common Options

Usage.name: Usage
Usage.description:
## Installation
```shell
ember install ember-cp-validations
```

## Changelog
Changelog can be found [here](https://github.com/offirgolan/ember-cp-validations/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md)

## Live Demo
A live demo can be found [here](http://offirgolan.github.io/ember-cp-validations/)

## Looking for help?
If it is a bug [please open an issue on GitHub](http://github.com/offirgolan/ember-cp-validations/issues).

Basic.name: Basic

Advanced.name: Advanced

V-Get Helper.name: V-Get Helper
V-Get Helper.description:
Accessing validation information in your templates is really simple but the pathing can be quite long. For example, if we want to display the error `message` for the `username` attribute, it would look something like this: ```handlebars {{model.validations.attrs.username.message}} ``` ## The V-Get Helper To bypass such long pathing, you can use the `v-get` helper. _**Notice**: Ember v1.13.0 is not supported due to a bug. Please use Ember v1.13.1 and higher or Ember v1.12.* and lower_ **Access global model properties** ```handlebars {{v-get model 'isValid'}} ``` **Access attribute specific properties** ```handlebars {{v-get model 'username' 'message'}} ``` **Access model relationship validations** Say we have a `user` model with a `details` attribute that is a belongsTo relationship, to access validations on the `details` attribute/model we can access it as such. ```handlebars {{v-get model.details 'isValid'}} {{v-get model.details 'firstName' 'message'}} ``` What's awesome about this is that you can pass in bound properties! ```handlebars {{v-get model attr prop}} {{v-get model prop}} ``` Here is a more extensive example: ```handlebars
{{input value=model.username placeholder="Username"}} {{#if (v-get model 'username' 'isInvalid')}}
{{v-get model 'username' 'message'}}
{{/if}}
```

Alias.name: Alias
Alias.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Creates an alias between a single attribute's validations to another. This copies all messages, errors, etc., to the current attribute as well as its validation state (isValid, isValidating, etc.) ## Examples ```javascript validator('alias', 'attribute') validator('alias', { alias: 'attribute', firstMessageOnly: true }) ```

Custom.name: Custom

Belongs To.name: Belongs To
Belongs To.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Identifies a `belongs-to` relationship in an Ember Data Model or Ember.Object. This is used to create a link to the validations object of the child model. _**Note:** Validations must exist on **both** models/objects_ ### Ember Model ```javascript // model/users.js const Validations = buildValidations({ details: validator('belongs-to') }); export default DS.Model.extend(Validations, { 'details': DS.belongsTo('user-detail') }); ``` ```javascript // model/user-details.js const Validations = buildValidations({ firstName: validator('presence', true), lastName: validator('presence', true) }); export default DS.Model.extend(Validations, { "firstName": attr('string'), "lastName": attr('string'), }); ``` ### Ember Object ```javascript // model/users.js import UserDetails from '../user-details'; const Validations = buildValidations({ details: validator('belongs-to') }); export default Ember.Object.extend(Validations, { details: null, init() { this._super(...arguments); let owner = Ember.getOwner(this); this.set('details', UserDetails.create(owner.ownerInjection())); } }); ``` From our `user` model, we can now check any validation property on the `user-details` model. ```javascript get(model, 'validations.attrs.details.isValid') get(model, 'validations.attrs.details.messages') ```

Collection.name: Collection
Collection.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) If `true` validates that the given value is a valid collection and will add `.[]` as a dependent key to the CP. If `false`, validates that the given value is singular. Use this validator if you want validation to occur when the content of your collection changes. ## Examples ```javascript validator('collection', true) validator('collection', false) validator('collection', { collection: true, message: 'must be a collection' }) ```

Confirmation.name: Confirmation
Confirmation.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Validates that the attribute has the same value as the one of the declared attribute. ## Examples ```javascript email: validator('format', { type: 'email' }) verifiedEmail: validator('confirmation', { on: 'email', message: 'Email addresses do not match' }) ```

Date.name: Date
Date.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Validate over a date range. Uses [MomentJS](http://momentjs.com/) for date mathematics and calculations. **Note**: MomentJS must be installed to be able to use this validator. The easiest way to do this is to install [ember-moment](https://github.com/stefanpenner/ember-moment) ## Examples If `before`, `onOrBefore`, `after`, or `onOrAfter` is set to **now**, the value given to the validator will be tested against the current date and time. ```javascript validator('date', { after: 'now', before: '1/1/2020', precision: 'day', format: 'M/D/YYY', errorFormat: 'M/D/YYY' }) ```

Dependent.name: Dependent
Dependent.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Defines an attribute as valid only if its dependents are valid. ## Example ```javascript // Full name will only be valid if firstName and lastName are filled in validator('dependent', { on: ['firstName', 'lastName'] }) ```

DS Error.name: DS Error
DS Error.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Creates a link between this library and Ember-Data's [DS.Errors](http://emberjs.com/api/data/classes/DS.Errors.html) to fetch the latest message for the given attribute. ## Examples ```javascript validator('ds-error') ```

Exclusion.name: Exclusion
Exclusion.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Validates that the attributesâ€™ values are not included in a given list. All comparisons are done using strict equality so type matters! For range, the value type is checked against both lower and upper bounds for type equality. ## Examples: ```javascript validator('exclusion', { in: ['Admin', 'Super Admin'] }) validator('exclusion', { range: [0, 5] // Cannot be between 0 (inclusive) to 5 (inclusive) }) ```

Format.name: Format
Format.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Validate over a predefined or custom regular expression. ## Examples ```javascript validator('format', { type: 'email', allowNonTld: true }) validator('format', { allowBlank: true, type: 'phone' }) validator('format', { type: 'url' }) validator('format', { regex: /^(?=.*\d)(?=.*[a-z])(?=.*[A-Z]).{4,8}$/, message: 'Password must include at least one upper case letter, one lower case letter, and a number' }) ``` If you do not want to use the predefined regex for a specific type, you can do something like this ```javascript validator('format', { type: 'email', regex: /My Better Email Regexp/ }) ``` This allows you to still keep the email error message but with your own custom regex.

Has Many.name: Has Many
Has Many.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Identifies a `has-many` relationship in an Ember Data Model or Ember.Object. This is used to create a validation collection of the `has-many` validations. _**Note:** Validations must exist on **all** models/objects_ ### Ember Models ```javascript // model/users.js const Validations = buildValidations({ friends: validator('has-many') }); export default DS.Model.extend(Validations, { friends: DS.hasMany('user') }); ``` ### Ember Objects ```javascript // model/users.js const Validations = buildValidations({ friends: validator('has-many') }); export default Ember.Object.extend(Validations, { friends: null }); ``` From our `user` model, we can now check validation properties on the `friends` attribute. ```javascript get(model, 'validations.attrs.friends.isValid') get(model, 'validations.attrs.friends.messages') ```

Inclusion.name: Inclusion
Inclusion.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Validates that the attributesâ€™ values are included in a given list. All comparisons are done using strict equality so type matters! For range, the value type is checked against both lower and upper bounds for type equality. ## Examples ```javascript validator('inclusion', { in: ['User', 'Admin'] }) validator('inclusion', { range: [0, 5] // Must be between 0 (inclusive) to 5 (inclusive) }) ``` Because of the strict equality comparisons, you can use this validator in many different ways. ```javascript validator('inclusion', { in: ['Admin'] // Input must be equal to 'Admin' }) validator('inclusion', { range: [0, Infinity] // Input must be positive number }) validator('inclusion', { range: [-Infinity, Infinity] // Input must be a number }) ```

Inline.name: Inline

Length.name: Length
Length.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Validates the length of the attributesâ€™ values. ## Examples ```javascript validator('length', { is: 15 }) validator('length', { min: 5, max: 10 }) ```

Messages.name: Messages

Number.name: Number
Number.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) Validates that your attributes have only numeric values. ## Examples ```javascript validator('number') // Simple check if the value is a number validator('number', { allowString: true, integer: true, gt: 5, lte: 100 }) ```

Presence.name: Presence
Presence.description: [See All Options](#method_validate) If `true` validates that the given value is not empty, if `false`, validates that the given value is empty. ## Examples ```javascript validator('presence', true) validator('presence', false) validator('presence', { presence: true, message: 'should not be empty' }) validator('presence', { presence: true, ignoreBlank: true, message: 'should not be empty or consist only of spaces' }) ```

classitems.description: The validator that returned this result
classitems.name: _validator

classitems.description:
Determines if the _result object is readOnly.

This is needed because ResultCollections and global validation objects control their own
state via CPs
classitems.name: _isReadOnly

classitems.description: This hold all the logic for the above CPs. We do this so we can easily switch this object out with a different validations object
classitems.name: _result

classitems.description:
Update the current validation result object with the given value
- If value is undefined or null, set isValid to false
- If value is a validations object from a different model/object, set the _result object to the one given (belongs-to)
- If value is a collection of result objects, create a Validation Result Collection and set that to the _result object (has-many)
- If value is a string, set the message to the given string and set isValid to false
- If value is a boolean, set isValid to result
- If value is a pojo, update _result object with the information given
classitems.name: update

classitems.description: Override the internal _result property.
classitems.name: _overrideResult

classitems.description: Promise handler
classitems.name: _handlePromise

classitems.hasvalidations:
(Validations)
export default class YourModel extends Model {

classitems.description:
Use Ember Meta to break cycles in the CP chains. Lets say we have a User model with a `friends` property that is a hasMany
relationship. If we have a user John and he has a friend Jane, that creates a two-way relationship. John is Jane's friends and vise
versa. If we were to go down the CP chain and get validations for John's friends, it would go to Jane, then to Jane's friends, which
would point back to John. This method tracks which models have been already visited and breaks the cycle.

Assigns a value to an object via the given path while creating new objects if
the pathing requires it. If the given path is `foo.bar`, it will create a new object (obj.foo)
and assign value to obj.foo.bar. If the given object is an Ember.Object, it will create new Ember.Objects.
Lookup a validator of a specific type on the owner

Checks if the give key exists on the object's super.
If so, we can successfully call the obj[key] _super

Created by @rwjblue
The error validator type

classitems.description: The error message
classitems.name: message

classitems.description: The parent attribute that the error belongs to

normalizeOptions

classitems.description:
Creates the validations class that will become `model.validations`.
  - Setup parent validation inheritance
  - Normalize nested keys (i.e. 'details.dob') into objects (i.e { details: { dob: validator() }})
  - Merge normalized validations with parent
  - Create global CPs (i.e. 'isValid', 'messages', etc...)

createAttrsClass

equal to the given value

Since the CPs are created once per class on the first initialization,

props.name: on
props.description: Only validate the given attributes. If empty, will validate over all validatable attribute

If `false`, will get all validations and will error if an async validations is found.
                             If `true`, will get all validations and wrap them in a promise hash

return.description: Promise if isAsync is true, object if isAsync is false

```javascript
let { m, validations } = model.validateSync();
validations.get('isValid') // true or false
```
classitems.name: validateSync

props.name: on
props.description: Only validate the given attributes. If empty, will validate over all validatable attribute

props.name: excludes

classitems.description:
```javascript

get(user, 'validations.isInvalid')

This property is toggled only if there is an async validation

Will be true only if isValid is `true` and isValidating is `false`

```javascript

```javascript

get(user, 'validations.isTruelyInvalid')

```

Will be `true` only if a validation returns a promise

// Examples

classitems.name: isAsync

classitems.description:
A collection of all error messages on the object in question

```javascript
// Examples
get(user, 'validations.messages')
get(user, 'validations.attrs.username.messages')
```
classitems.name: messages

classitems.description:
An alias to the first message in the messages collection.

```javascript
// Example
get(user, 'validations.message')
get(user, 'validations.attrs.username.message')
```
classitems.name: message

classitems.description:
Will be `true` if there are warnings in the collection.

```javascript

get(user, 'validations.hasWarnings')

```

classitems.description:

```javascript
// Examples
get(user, 'validations.warningMessages')
get(user, 'validations.attrs.username.warningMessages')
```
classitems.name: warningMessages

classitems.description:
An alias to the first message in the warningMessages collection.

```javascript
// Example
get(user, 'validations.warningMessage')
get(user, 'validations.attrs.username.warningMessage')
```
classitems.name: warningMessage

classitems.description:
A collection of all {{#crossLink "Error"}}Warnings{{/crossLink}} on the object in question.
Each warning object includes the warning message and it's associated attribute name.

```javascript
// Example
get(user, 'validations.warnings')

```

classitems.description:
An alias to the first {{#crossLink "Warning"}}{{/crossLink}} in the warnings collection.

```javascript
// Example

```
classitems.name: warning

classitems.description:
A collection of all {{#crossLink "Error"}}Errors{{/crossLink}} on the object in question.
Each error object includes the error message and it's associated attribute name.

```javascript

get(user, 'validations.attrs.username.errors')
```
classitems.name: errors

classitems.description:
An alias to the first {{#crossLink "Error"}}{{/crossLink}} in the errors collection.

```javascript
// Example
get(user, 'validations.error')
get(user, 'validations.attrs.username.error')
```
classitems.name: error

classitems.description:
All built options of the validators associated with the results in this collection grouped by validator type

```javascript
// Given the following validators
{
  username: [
    validator('presence', true),
    validator('length', { max: 15 }),
    validator('format', { regex: /foo/ }),
    validator('format', { regex: /bar/ }),
  ]
}
```

```js
get(user, 'validations.attrs.username.options')
```

The above will return the following
```js
{
  'presence': { presence: true},
  'length': { max: 15 },
  'regex': [{ regex: /foo/ }, { regex: /bar/ }]
}
```
classitems.name: options

classitems.description:
Used by the `options` property to create a hash from the `content` that is grouped by validator type.
If there is more than 1 of a type, it groups it into an array of option objects.

classitems.description:
Build options hook. Merges default options into options object.
This method gets called on init and is the ideal place to normalize your options.
The [presence validator](https://github.com/offirgolan/ember-cp-validations/blob/master/addon/validators/presence.js) is a good example to checkout
classitems.name: buildOptions

classitems.description:
Used to retrieve the value to validate.
This method gets called right before `validate` and the returned value
gets passed into the validate method.
classitems.name: value

classitems.description: Wrapper method to `value` that passes the necessary parameters
classitems.name: getValue

classitems.description:
The validate method is where all of your logic should go.
It will get passed in the current value of the attribute this validator is attached to.
Within the validator object, you will have access to the following properties:
classitems.name: validate

params.name: value
params.description: The current value of the attribute

return.description:
One of the following types:
- `Boolean`:  `true` if the current value passed the validation
- `String`: The error message
- `Promise`: A promise that will either resolve or reject, and will finally return either `true` or the final error message string.

classitems.name: createErrorMessage

params.name: type
params.description: The type of message template to use

params.name: options
params.description: Validator built and processed options (used as the message string context)

classitems.name: test

params.name: type
params.description:
The validator type (e.x. 'presence', 'length', etc.)
                         The following types are unsupported:
                           'alias', 'belongs-to', 'dependent', 'has-many'

params.name: args
params.description: The arguments to pass through to the validator

return.description:
The test result object which will contain `isValid`
                         and `message`. If the validator is async, then the
                         return value will be a promise.

classitems.description: Generate the needed dependent keys for this validator
classitems.name: getDependentsFor
buildOptions

props.name: on
props.description: Attributes this field is dependent on

classitems.description:
Override the validator's `validate` method with the one that was
passed in via the options.

buildOptions

classitems.description: {{#if (v-get model 'username' 'isValid')}} {{/if}}
{{x-component prop=(v-get model 'isValid')}}

<button type="submit" disabled={{v-get model 'isInvalid'}}>Submit</button> (node.attributes)
<div class="form-group {{if (v-get model 'isInvalid') 'has-error'}}">

Transform:
 (v-get model 'username' 'isValid') to (get (get (get (get model 'validations') 'attrs') 'username') 'isValid')
OR
 (v-get model 'isValid') to (get (get model 'validations') 'isValid')

If true validates that the given value is not empty,
                                  if false, validates that the given value is empty.

props.name: ignoreBlank
props.description: If true, treats an empty or whitespace string as not present

warnings.message: replacing incorrect tag: returns with return
replacing incorrect tag: returns with return

Missing item type
Decorator that allows you to mixin validations when using es6 style model classes

Usage:

import { hasValidations } from 'ember-cp-validations';

Missing item type
Use Ember Meta to break cycles in the CP chains. Lets say we have a User model with a `friends` property that is a hasMany
relationship. If we have a user John and he has a friend Jane, that creates a two-way relationship. John is Jane's friends and vise
versa. If we were to go down the CP chain and get validations for John's friends, it would go to Jane, then to Jane's friends, which
would point back to John. This method tracks which models have been already visited and breaks the cycle.

Missing item type
Assigns a value to an object via the given path while creating new objects if
the pathing requires it. If the given path is `foo.bar`, it will create a new object (obj.foo)
and assign value to obj.foo.bar. If the given object is an Ember.Object, it will create new Ember.Objects.

Missing item type
Lookup a validator of a specific type on the owner

Missing item type
Checks if the give key exists on the object's super.
If so, we can successfully call the obj[key] _super

Created by @rwjblue

Missing item type
Used by the `options` property to create a hash from the `content` that is grouped by validator type.
If there is more than 1 of a type, it groups it into an array of option objects.

Missing item type
<button type="submit" disabled={{v-get model 'isInvalid'}}>Submit</button> (node.attributes)
<div class="form-group {{if (v-get model 'isInvalid') 'has-error'}}">

Missing item type
Transform:
 (v-get model 'username' 'isValid') to (get (get (get (get model 'validations') 'attrs') 'username') 'isValid')
OR
 (v-get model 'isValid') to (get (get model 'validations') 'isValid')

Missing item type
Default validation error message strings
